div1.p: Legation of the Republic of Liberia Yonkers, N.Y. April 7, 1866
I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your lettersof 26th ult. and of 5th instant, the latter recognizing Mr. Wm Coppinger as Chief of this Legation.

I beg to inform you that I have received from the Liberian government a special com mission, iwht full powers to negotiate with the government of the United States for the purchase of a steam gun boat of not over 150 tons. One of not over 120 tons with one eighteen pound pivot gun would be most suitable.

The govt. of Liberia is particularly anxious to have such a vessel for other reasons besides teh suppression of the slave trade, having, (since the disability of the schooner Quail theirs only gun vessel) suffered

for many monthsdgreat inconvenience in the collection of revenue and the enforcement of order among the tribes on different parts of their coast, and much annoyance out of difficulties between foreigners and the natives within their jurisdiction they would have been saved from had not the Quail been disabled.

Libera having been colonized exclusively by persons without capital, (unlike any country newly sealed by whites not having the benefit of foreign capital into it (for their )race in other countries, few excpetions, have but little) is compelled to much economy and yet its great need of a vessel, renders the government of LIberia willing to incur a debt for
The government Liberia is conscious that pecuniary considerations could not move the government of > United States to transfer a gun boat and yet the bill, as it has passed
Senate, seems to me to restrict and limit the discretion of the Executive Department so that no other consideration can be admitted in arranging for the transfer.

It would be happy for Liberia and more in accordance wiwth her pecunniary resources, if the bill would be modified so as to allow other considerations to be admitted in fiding the coast, for instance, the convenience she would afford to the United States govenrment in pro- viding more frequent communications with any fleet or vessels on her coast s she would be kept in as frequent intercourse as possible with all parts of it, and as the Liberians (as President Warner in a late letter says) "are in feelings, sentiment and disposition, America.

The United States being engaged with Great Britain in the suppression of the slave trade, could effect much with such a boat in the hands of the Libera Government without the expense of keeping her in
commission, an expense probably annually equally to her value, possibly England was induced by some such considerations in to generosity in the gift of the Qual.
I have the honor to be with the highest consideration. Sir your most obedient servant. H.M. Scheiffelin
Hon. W.H. Seward Secretary of State Washington D.C.
